source.title: Partial cutting in a second-growth Douglas-fir stand in coastal British Columbia – productivity, costs, and soil impacts
source.site: 33 ha block on Quadra Island (CWHxm2) operated October 1991–March 1992
source.prescription: Multiple-entry partial cut removing 12–15% of stand volume per entry via pre-marked dispersed trees; true clearcut only in small root-rot pocket.

operation.crew: Two-person crew (chainsaw faller + JD450G operator sharing JD540 rubber-tired skidder duty).
operation.skidding_network: 4 m designated skid roads spaced ~100 m apart; JD450G permitted to travel off road network for dispersed retrieval; JD540 restricted to roads.
equipment: John Deere 450G crawler tractor with winch and chokers
John Deere 540 cable skidder (used intermittently for forwarding along roads)

soil_and_damage.disturbance_notes: Soil bulk density significantly higher on designated skid roads than in lightly used dispersed trails; light/heavy dispersed traffic did not differ statistically at 0–20 cm depth.

usage_notes: Dataset represents low-removal (≈14% volume) skyline-compatible partial cutting with CPI-aware costing. Use as a penalty reference when modelling dispersed retention prescriptions beyond the TR119 strip/70/65% presets.
